text:
- [Ali] In this video,
we're going to be chatting
about AWS Amplify Studio.

We'll use the backend
data modeling capabilities
to create a quotes data model.

And then we'll use the
Figma to code functionality
to create React components
based off of our designers designs.

We'll display all of
our quotes on the page
and also create a form.

When we're done, the
application will look like this.
And a form to create a new quote.
There will also be a search

so that you can find different
quotes or different authors.

I'm Ali Spittel, I lead developer
advocacy for AWS Amplify.

And I'm gonna be teaching
you all about Amplify
throughout this tutorial.

First, I'll go to the AWS
console and go to AWS Amplify.

From here, I'll create a new
app and select build an app.

If you're new to Amplify,
there will be two options
on a landing page instead.

I'll choose an app name and
then confirm deployment.

Now that I have a Studio instance,
I'll click Launch Studio.
Now I'll go to create data model.

I'll call each motivational
quote a thought
and each one is going to have an author
as well as some text.
Both of these will be string fields,
but if I needed to change them, I could.
Now I'll save and deploy.

Note that I could also
create multiple data models
and have relationships between them.
Now that my data model has deployed,
I'm gonna go to the UI Library tab.
I'll click Get Started.

And here you can use the
Figma template to get started.
You can click Duplicate here

and you can also use the
AWS Amplify Theme Editor.

In Figma, I went ahead and
customize some components.
So here's an item card.
This will be what stores a quote.
Here's a form to create a quote.
So it has the name and then the quote.

And then I have a hero
for the top of the page.

And I went into this AWS
Amplify Theme Editor plugin
and I added different brand colors.
In my case, a yellow and a pink.

And I made sure that all
of my different components
follow the colors that I wanted to have.
I'll copy the URL of my Figma file
and paste it into this Figma file link.
My theme will load in

and then I can accept
or reject components.
I'll select accept all.

I'll start with the item
card and click Configure.

From here, I'll set the text
label to the thought.text.

And then I'll set the text
label to the thought.author.

By default, this will show you
randomly generated thoughts,

but I can add some content so
that my actual quote show up.
I'll switch over to the Content tab.
Now if I go back to my component,
my actual data will load in
and I can shuffle to see all of them.
I'm gonna create a collection

since I want all of my different
thoughts to be displayed.
I'll call my collection Thoughts.

I'll add in search and
I'll also add pagination
if there are more than 30 quotes.
I'm gonna create a grid
and add in three columns instead of two.

I'll add 10 pixels of margin
on each side of my cards.

You can also add different
filters or sort conditions
if you want to show a subset of your data
or your data in a specific order.
Now I'll go to this CreateQuote form.

I'm gonna start off with
setting this placeholder
to an inspirational thought.
Then on save, I'll add an on click action.
And in this case,

I'll create a new instance
of the Thought model.
The author will be the name here
and then the text will be the quote.
Now my form is good to go.

Now for my hero, I'll
click Configure again.
This top text, I'll just set as a daisy.
This one I'll say Happy Thoughts.

I'll set the text label here
to motivational quotes there.
And then for this button here,

I'm going to set the label
to be Create Thought.
And I'll also set an on click action.
This one will go to URL
and that URL will be /create thought.

I also want to set this image
to a picture of daisies.
Now that I have my components configured
and tied to my data,

I want to add this to
my local application.
I'm gonna create a Next.js application
called motivational quotes.

You could also use
create-react-app if you want.
I'm just gonna use Next.js for routing.

I'm not gonna use any of the
SSR, SSG that it provides.

I'll change into the
directory that I just created.

And I'm gonna go to
local setup instructions.

I'll copy this command and
piece it into my terminal.
I'll log into the CLI,

choose my editor and select
all the defaults here.
A quick note, you will need

to install the Amplify
command line interface
if you haven't already.
There are instructions on how to do that

under View Amplify CLI
Installation Instructions.
I'll open up the code in my text editor.
And within source,
you can see that Amplify generated models
to go along with my Thought model
as well as these UI components.

If you go into them, you
can see that they model
what you would do as a developer

and all of the names fit according
to the names of the items
that you create within Figma.

Each one also has the
ability to be overridden.
So you can use this key
in order to write your own custom code
for any of these components.
I'll need to install the Amplify libraries
and UI components.

Now I'm gonna go into my _app
JS file and configure Amplify.
The AWS-exports is the configuration file

with all the information about
where my backend is on AWS.
And so when I run the amplify.configure,
it will tie my front end to my backend
that I already created.
I'll import the AmplifyProvider component

and use it as the top
level of my application.

This will pass theming
down to my whole app.
I created that UI theme within Figma.
So I'm gonna go into my UI components

and you'll see that there's a
Studio theme that's generated.

I'll pass my Studio theme
to the AmplifyProvider
as the theme prop.
The last thing that I need
to configure is the Amplify CSS file.
Now I'll move to my index.js file.
I'll clear out what's here now.

And I'll render the
HeroLayout1 on the page.

Note that I'll need to import
it from the UI components.
I'll start my development server.
Now you can see that my hero component
is rendered on the page.
There are two things that I wanna do,

first make it so that it is
100% the width of the page.

The other one is to
import the Amplify fonts.
If you go to ui.docs.amplify.aws

and then scroll down on
the installation page,
you'll see a link to a font.

You can also use a font
that you wanna use as well.
I'll piece this into my styles global.css.
Now my fonts, the nice sans serif
that I was seeing in Studio.

I'll set the width to 100%
and now it stretches the page
instead of just being part of it.

Now I wanna render my
quotes underneath it.

The thoughts will also be
imported from the UI components.
I'll add a margin bottom to my hero layout

so that my search doesn't
interfere with my hero.
All of the data that I created

within the Amplify CMS
loads onto the page.

The last thing that I need
to do is implement my form.
When I click on that Create button,
it redirects me to Create Thought.
I'm gonna create a Next.js route for this.
Create a file called the create-thought.

And I'll create a React
component within it.
I'll import the CreateQuote form.
And now let's test it out.

I'll add in a random
name and then click Save.

Now if I go to my homepage,
my new quote loaded in.
It saves a lot of time compared
to writing a form from scratch.
Everything in these generated components
are overridable within code.

You can again pass an
override object to a component
in order to override anything within them.
You can pass override items

to a collection like
these quotes down here

and that will allow you
to modify certain items
within that collection.

In this video, we created a
data model within Amplify Studio

and then used Amplify
Studios Figma to React

in order to generate React
components from Figma designs.

We then added it all to
a Next.js application.

If you wanted to, you
could add authentication

through Amplify Studio or
storage for files as well.
I'd love to see what you build

as you continue creating
with AWS Amplify Studio.
